definitions.definition: not securely fixed where it should be; able to become separated from something

examples.text: a loose button/tooth
Check that the plug has not **come loose**.
One of the bricks feels slightly loose.
Darien shook his arm loose.

definitions.definition: not tied together; not held in position by anything or contained in anything

examples.text: She usually wears her hair loose.
He tucked a loose strand of hair behind his ear.
The potatoes were sold loose, not in bags.

definitions.definition: free to move around without control; not tied up or shut in somewhere

examples.text: The sheep had got out and were loose on the road.
The horse had **broken loose** *(= escaped)* from its tether.
The animals ran loose without collars or leashes.
During the night, somebody had cut the boat loose from its moorings.

definitions.definition: not fitting closely

examples.text: On long flights, wear loose clothing and comfortable shoes.
a loose shirt

definitions.definition: not tightly packed together; not solid or hard

examples.text: loose soil
a fabric with a loose weave

definitions.definition: not strictly organized or managed

examples.text: a **loose alliance/coalition/federation**
a loose association of artists, writers and composers

definitions.definition: not exact; not very careful

examples.text: This is only a loose translation as I am not fluent in Japanese.
This book is an antidote for much of the loose thinking in the world of today.
The committees work within fairly loose guidelines.

definitions.definition: having or involving an attitude to sexual relationships that people consider to be morally wrong

examples.text: a young man of loose morals

definitions.definition: not in any player’s control

examples.text: He pounced on a **loose ball**.

definitions.definition: having too much liquid in it

examples.text: a baby with loose bowel movements

definitions.definition: suddenly there was a lot of noise, arguing, fighting, etc.

examples.text: There was a loud bang and then all hell broke loose.

definitions.definition: to separate yourself or somebody/something from a group of people or their influence, etc.

examples.text: The organization broke loose from its sponsors.
He cut himself loose from his family.

definitions.definition: to remain calm; to not worry

examples.text: It's OK—hang loose and stay cool.

definitions.definition: to talk too much, especially about things that are private
to be slightly strange in your behaviour
to do something or to happen in a way that no one controls

examples.text: Teenagers need a place to let loose.

definitions.definition: to make a noise or remark, especially in a loud or sudden way

examples.text: She let loose a stream of abuse.

definitions.definition: to free somebody/something from whatever holds them/it in place

examples.text: She let her hair loose and it fell around her shoulders.
Who's let the dog loose?

definitions.definition: to give somebody complete freedom to do what they want in a place or situation

examples.text: He was at last let loose in the kitchen.
A team of professionals were let loose on the project.

definitions.definition: to treat somebody/something in a way that shows that you feel no responsibility or respect for them

wordOrigin: Middle English loos ‘free from bonds’, from Old Norse lauss, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German los.
